BufferedImage image = ImageIO.read(new File("path_to_your_image"));
BufferedImage resizedImage = resizeUsingImageIO(image, 100); // Resize the image to 100x100 pixels
ByteArrayOutputStream baos = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
ImageIO.write(resizedImage, "jpg", baos);
baos.flush();
byte[] imageInByte = baos.toByteArray();
int sizeInKb = imageInByte.length / 1024; // size of image in kb

if(sizeInKb > MAX_SIZE_IN_KB) {
    // Resize the image again
    resizedImage = resizeUsingImageIO(image, 90); // Resize the image to 90x90 pixels
    baos = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
    ImageIO.write(resizedImage, "jpg", baos);
    baos.flush();
    imageInByte = baos.toByteArray();
    sizeInKb = imageInByte.length / 1024; // size of image in kb
}

If the size is greater than a specified maximum size (in kilobytes), it resizes the image again and converts it to a byte array. The process continues until the size of the byte array is less than or equal to the maximum size.

Note: The maximum size in kilobytes (MAX_SIZE_IN_KB) should be defined based on your specific requirements. The resizing process can be adjusted based on the specific needs of your application.

Also, please note that the ImageIO.write method can throw an IOException, so you should handle this exception appropriately in your code.
